bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George Carroll, July 11, 1941

div1.p: Hench describes the Cornwell painting and explains that the tribute to Carroll's father is brief because there is little in the official records about his work.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George Carroll, July 11, 1941
div1.opener:
July 15, 41
C O P Y
Copy to Gen Kean
July 11, 1941
Mr. George I. H. Carroll
2814 Rhode Island Ave., N. E.
Washington, D. C.
My dear Mr. Carroll:
div1.p:
I thought you would be interested in having a few photographs of
the remains of Camp Lazear in Havana. I took them either last year or this
April when I went to visit Havana again. I believe I told you over the
phone when I talked with you early last month that I had been fortunate
enough to “rediscover” the lost Camp Lazear. You will find on the back
comments identifying the photographs. I am sure you will be interested to
see the present condition of Camp Lazear especially the present state of the
famous little “Building Number One” which is still in existence and which
is where your father and Walter Reed and the others accomplished their won-
derful work. I am hoping to arrange to have the site of Camp Lazear and
the little building properly preserved as a memorial to last for all time
to the memory of your father and his colleagues.

As I told you in my letter of May 23, the Wyeth Company, an old
and reputable American pharmaceutical house, commissioned Mr. Dean Cornwell,
a famous American painter, to do a large painting, entitled “Conquerors of
Yellow Fever”. This painting was unveiled in Cleveland June 2, during the
convention of the American Medical Association. The unveiling was made by
Walter Reed's daughter, Miss Blossom Reed. Mr. Kissinger was there, also
the mayor of Cleveland, the President and President-elect of the American
Medical Association, representatives from various medical schools and art
museums and a few people from Washington, among them Colonel Siler and
General and Mrs. Ireland. It was really a very nice affair and the paint-
ing was very well received. I am sorry you could not be there. (As I
wrote you I don't think the Wyeth people had your address, hence they may
not have known where to send you an invitation.)

He never
answered
this letter
but I'll keep
on!

But in time you shall see copies of the painting and I am sure
you will like to have one. The central action of the painting shows Dr.
Lazear inoculating your father. Grouped behind and on either side are
others involved--Reed, Finlay, Agramonte, Gen. Wood, and a group of soldier
volunteers. Altogether it is a very stimulating and historical scene.

I had the honor of being asked to make some remarks at the un-
veiling and I am taking the liberty of sending you a copy of my talk. I
do hope you accept it in the spirit I send it--as a very earnest tribute
Mr. George I. H. Carroll
- 2 -
July 11, 1941
to a very gallant group of men. If my tribute to your father seems brief
it is chiefly because, unfortunately it is difficult to find in the official
records as much about your father's actions and work as that about certain
others.

Would you permit me to send your address to the Wyeth folks so
they can send you a colored reproduction of the painting when they are
available in a few weeks?
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
